metadata.case_name: Former Ruler of Sonepur v. State of Orissa

facts.text: Legislature of Province of Orissa enacted Orissa Agricultural Income-tax Act XXIV of 1947, providing for levy of income-tax on agricultural income from lands in Province of Orissa, brought into operation from July 10, 1947.

By s. 3 of the Act, agricultural income-tax payable for each financial year on total income of previous year of every person; proviso exempts agricultural income of Central Government, State Government or local authority.
Section 2 cl. 1 defines 'person' as inclusive of Ruler of an Indian State.
Appellant is former Ruler of State of Sonepur.
After August 15, 1947, appellant executed instrument of accession to Dominion of India restricted to Defence, External Affairs and Communications.

On December 15, 1947, appellant executed merger agreement whereby territory of Sonepur merged with Dominion of India; Government of India acquired full sovereign rights, but guaranteed ownership of private properties to appellant under Art. 3.

By notification dated March 23, 1948, under Extra Provincial Jurisdiction Act 1947, Government of India delegated full powers to Provincial Government of Orissa to administer merged States including Sonepur.
Government of Orissa applied s. 1 of Act to merged States from January 19, 1949, and remaining provisions from April 1, 1949.

Ss. 290A and 290B incorporated in Government of India Act, 1935; Governor-General issued order on July 27, 1949, that merged Orissa States including Sonepur administered as part of Province of Orissa from August 1, 1949.
On December 30, 1949, Governor of Orissa promulgated Ordinance No. IV of 1949 applying Agricultural Income-tax Act 1947 to merged Orissa States, replaced by Orissa Merged States Laws Act XVI of 1950.
Appellant called upon by Agricultural Income-tax Officer to furnish return of agricultural income; appellant disputed liability and declined.
Agricultural Income-tax Officer assessed appellant for years 1949-50 to 1953-54 and imposed penalty for failure to submit returns for 1949-50 and 1950-51.
Appellant appealed to Assistant Collector of Agricultural Income-tax, Sambalpur; appeals dismissed.
Revision applications to Collector of Commercial Taxes, Cuttack and Board of Revenue unsuccessful.
Appellant filed petitions in Orissa High Court: Nos. 16,19,137,61 of 1954 challenging assessments for 1949-50 to 1952-53, and Nos. 18,138 against penalties for 1949-50,1950-51.

Orissa High Court (judgment August 1, 1956) held properties not immune from tax under merger agreement; appellant is 'person' under Act; dismissed petitions for 1950-51,1951-52,1952-53; cancelled assessment for 1949-50 and penalties.
Appeals to Supreme Court with certificate under Art. 132 against High Court dismissal for 1950-51,1951-52,1952-53.

Merger agreement: Art. 1 ceded full authority to Dominion; Art. 3 entitled appellant to full ownership of private properties (not State properties); Art. 4 personal privileges of Raja etc. enjoyed before Aug 15,1947; Art. 5 guaranteed succession and personal rights, privileges, dignities, titles.
Assessing authority held appellant holder of lands in 42 villages; appellant claimed 2 villages transferred to Yuvrani in 1945, rejected under s.14 cl.1; not raised in High Court.
Appellant's inventory to Government listed 18 villages, accepted by Government of India; plea not raised in High Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether appellant, former Ruler of Sonepur, is liable to pay agricultural income-tax under Orissa Act on income from private properties post-merger, or immune by virtue of merger agreement Arts. 4 and 5 and Art. 362 of Constitution.
Whether privileges under merger agreement extend to immunity from taxation on personal property.
Whether appellant is a 'person' under s.2 cl.1 of the Act post-Adaptation of Laws Order 1950.
Whether Art. 362 makes merger agreement enforceable to exempt from tax.

petitioner_arguments.text: As Ruler before merger, immune from taxation on private property within and outside State; immunity protected by Arts. 4 and 5 of merger agreement guaranteeing personal rights, privileges, dignities, titles enjoyed before Aug 15,1947.
Merger agreement incorporated in Art. 362; legislation must be interpreted to give effect to guarantee of tax immunity.
Two villages transferred to Yuvrani in 1945, income not taxable in appellant's hands.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.14 cl.1 Orissa Agricultural Income-tax Act

petitioner_arguments.text: Liable only for 18 villages listed in accepted inventory.

respondent_arguments.text: Properties not rendered immune from tax by merger agreement guarantee of ownership; no express exemption; appellant is 'person' under Act.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: s.3 Orissa Agricultural Income-tax Act; s.2 cl.1

court_reasoning.text: Sovereignty extinguished by merger; privileges under Arts. 4,5 are personal, do not extend to personal property or tax immunity.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Guarantee limited to personal rights, privileges, dignities qua Ruler; personal property different.

court_reasoning.text: Act imposes tax on every person; no exemption for appellant; amendment to s.2 cl.1 deleted reference to Rulers due to political changes, not to exempt.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Post-1950, no Indian States; appellant ceased to be Ruler.

court_reasoning.text: Art. 362 recommends due regard to guarantees but imports no enforceable legal obligation; cannot question legislation under Art. 363.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Claim seeks to enforce merger agreement terms, justiciable only via Art. 226 but rejected.

court_reasoning.text: Subsidiary contentions on 2 villages and inventory not raised in High Court, rejected.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No opportunity for respondent; no finding by High Court.

holdings.text: Appellant liable to agricultural income-tax under s.3 of Act; no immunity from merger agreement or Art. 362.
Privileges under Arts. 4,5 do not extend to tax immunity on property.
Art. 362 not enforceable; claim not justiciable.

precedents_cited.case_name: Visweshwar Rao v. State of Madhya Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Art. 4 of merger agreement guarantees personal rights qua Ruler, not personal property.

statutes_cited.name: Orissa Agricultural Income-tax Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Imposes tax on agricultural income of every person; defines person; proviso exempts governments; s.14 on transfers.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Certificate for appeal; writ petitions; privy purse; due regard to guarantees but non-enforceable; bars questioning covenants.

statutes_cited.name: Government of India Act, 1935
statutes_cited.relevance: Power to administer merged States as part of Province.

statutes_cited.name: Extra Provincial Jurisdiction Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Delegation of powers to Orissa Government.

statutes_cited.name: Orissa Merged States Laws Act, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Applied Agricultural Income-tax Act to merged States.

statutes_cited.name: Adaptation of Laws Order, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Deleted reference to Rulers of Indian States in s.2 cl.1.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed appeals Nos. 307, 308 and 309 of 1958, upholding Orissa High Court orders dismissing challenges to assessments for 1950-51, 1951-52 and 1952-53; held appellant liable to tax under the Act, no immunity from merger agreement.

key_quotes.text: "The guarantee or assurance to which due regard is to be had is limited to personal rights, privileges and dignities of the Ruler qua a Ruler. It does not extend to personal property which is different from personal rights."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejecting extension of privileges to property tax immunity; citing Das J.

key_quotes.text: Art. 362 "does not import any legal obligation enforceable at the instance of the erstwhile Ruler of a former Indian State."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Art. 362 merely recommends due regard, not enforceable.

key_quotes.text: "Liability to pay tax is imposed by the Act and there is in the Act no express exemption in favour of the appellant."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Direct basis for upholding tax liability.
